results.title: A Hungarian fairy tale = Hol volt, Hol nem volt [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Lajos Ovari, Hungarofilm, Objective Productions and Gyula Gazdag
results.brief_description: This strange, beautifully realised, almost wordless film combines gritty social realism and symbolic poeticism to tell the story of a boy’s fruitless search for his father. The film begins with a highly romantic scene in which a beautiful young woman and a handsome stranger meet at a performance of ‘The Magic Flute,’—an encounter that results in a passionate one-night-stand and the birth of a child. Though the father is never heard of again, Hungarian law states that every child must, by the age of three, have a father’s name entered on their birth certificate. The woman, with the encouragement of the bureaucrat who completes the form for her, invents a fictional name, address and occupation for the father. Years later, after his mother’s untimely death, the boy, now in his teens, sets out to find his mythic father. Beginning as a satire about Hungarian bureaucracy, the film introduces surreal and comic elements as the boy’s journey progresses. Eventually it evolves into a provocative allegorical fantasy about Hungarian identity and politics. Features a particularly strong performance by David Vermes as the teenage boy and impressive black and white photography. Cast also includes Maria Varga, Frantisek Husak and Eszter Csakanyi.
results.title_for_label: A Hungarian fairy tale = Hol volt, Hol nem volt [NTSC]
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lajos Ovari, Hungarofilm, Objective Productions and Gyula Gazdag

results.title: A Hundred years underground
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, British Transport Films, Edgar H. Anstey, John Shearman and Jon Rowdon
results.brief_description: The story of London’s underground railway, from the building of the original Metropolitan line with its steam drawn trains, to its latest addition, the ultra modern Victorian line. Lord Morrison tells how London Transport became the model for similar undertakings throughout the world; artist Henry Moore shows how the tube became a wartime refuge, and tunnel engineers explain the problems, past, present and future, of building and operating this vast system.
results.creator_credit_for_label: BBC-TV, British Transport Films, Edgar H. Anstey, John Shearman and Jon Rowdon

results.title: A Hundred-Odd Years From Now
results.creator_credit: Fred Schepisi, Australian Dried Fruits Association and Film House Company
results.brief_description: An advertising film with a difference: Into a strange computerised future where women “run things” by controlling huge colourful computers that go bleep booble bob bob ping etc, comes Yockoo, the boy from the bush, with his satchel of dried fruits. Slowly the women overcome their cold, futuristic ways in light of Yockoo’s size, shape and overall manliness. Eventually they unearth their deep feminine sexuality and cook Yockoo a feast of dried fruit dishes using cooking utensils from their local museum. Music by Frank Smith, Photographed by Lars Gundlach, Written and designed by Weatherhead & Stitt.

results.title: A housewife in Seoul
results.creator_credit: You Dang-Kyu, Gian Manara, Lee Kyu-Im, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, KBS Korea and Asian Broadcasting Union
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “A Day in the Life of a Woman”.
Kim Nan-Hi is a middle-class housewife in a high rise development on the outskirts of Seoul. This program looks at her daily life, her dedication to her children’s education and the family at work and play together, illustrating the Confucian philosophy that “great happiness has been found in the small pleasures of the family”. Introduced by Franca Arena.

results.title: A House on the prairie
results.creator_credit: Jerry Krepakevich, ONF | NFB, Ron Bashford and Bob Lower
results.brief_description: The promise of riches in a new land lured many settlers to the West, but it was a harsh climate where shelter was the most urgent necessity. A House on the Prairie describes the legacy of these early days: environmentally unsuitable dwellings that now either devour money and fuel to remain functional, or slowly disintegrate in the sun, wind and frost. People today are beginning to recognize the importance of housing suitable to specific environments, and some of these new examples of western Canadian architecture are presented, with comments by designers, builders, and the people who live in the somewhat experimental dwellings.

results.title: A House divided: caregiver stress and elder abuse
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, John Spotton, Silva Basmajian and Lyn Wright
results.brief_description: Through four moving portraits, A House Divided sheds light on the tragedy of caregiver stress and elder abuse. The abuse takes many forms, ranging from willful neglect and financial exploitation to physical assault. With great sensitivity, this film portrays the emotional complexity of family relationships that can lead to abuse of the elderly, the anguish and isolation of its victims, and the tremendous need for community understanding and support.
results.title_for_label: A House divided: caregiver stress and elder abuse
results.creator_credit_for_label: ONF | NFB, John Spotton, Silva Basmajian and Lyn Wright

results.title: A Horse with stripes
results.creator_credit: Andrew Ross, AFTRS and Andrew O'Sullivan
results.brief_description: Manicured lawns…immaculate houses…clean streets…but beneath this highly desirable exterior lurks the desperation of the bored, the scared, the paranoid and the violent. And when the tranquil suburban life of the Goldings and the Bates deteriorates into chaos, they choose not to speak about it. Winner of Silver Hugo, Best short drama, Chicago International Film Festival, USA, 1991.

results.title: A Horse's world
results.creator_credit: Louise Jones, Wall to Wall Television, Learning Channel, ITV and Steve Ruggi
results.brief_description: The horse is a paradox - a prey animal who lost his independence and submits to man’s enslavement - yet is also a symbol of dignity and freedom. This video looks at man’s most noble friend from an entirely new perspective; that of the horse itself. Innovative camera techniques show the world from a horse-eye-view as new research explains why horses behave like they do, allowing the viewer a greater understanding of horses and their behaviour.
